title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: SimtblR lightweight package brings together three essential tools epidemiologic analysis: tb() – Create publication-ready descriptive tables diag_test() – Evaluate diagnostic test performance regtab() – Generate multi-outcome regression tables Let’s explore function practical examples using realistic dataset.

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: First, load package example data:
code: library(SimtablR) #> ── SimtablR 1.0.0 ───────────────────── Simple R functions for usefull tables ── #> ✔ tb(): Descriptive tables (One-Table) #> ✔ diag_test(): Confusion matrix and Diagnostic Values #> ✔ regtab(): Regression Tables by Outcome (GLM) #> Use suppressPackageStartupMessages() to silence. data(epitabl)

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: epitabl dataset comes hypothetical cross-sectional study 500 adults examining risk factors chronic disease. Let’s get acquainted: study includes demographics (age, sex, education), health behaviors (smoking, exercise), clinical measures (BMI, blood pressure, cholesterol), outcomes (disease status, healthcare utilization, hospitalization). note disease: 30% participants disease, making realistic prevalence many chronic conditions:
code: tb(epitabl, disease) #>  Disease status (primary outcome) | Freq  #> ----------------------------------+------ #>                                No | 331   #>                               Yes | 169

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: tb() function Swiss Army knife SimtablR. designed replace base R table() function good part workflow. handles: Counts Percentages (Row, Column, Total) Statistical Tests (Chi-squared, Fisher, McNemar) Effect Measures (Prevalence Ratios, Odds Ratios) Stratification (3-way tables) Formatting publication (Flextable integration)

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: real association, pattern occur chance? Set test = TRUE automatically calculate p-value (Chi-squared Fisher’s exact test, depending sample size). can also determine manually. frequency tables, can set "chsqr" (Pearson’s Chi-squared), "fisher" (Fisher’s Exact Test) "mcnemar" (McNemar). see something interesting. prevalence varies across smoking groups, p-value suggests unlikely due chance alone.
code: tb(epitabl, smoking, disease, col, test= "chsqr") #could also use test= TRUE #>                 | Disease status (primary outcome)  #>  Smoking status |     No          Yes     | Sum  #> ----------------+-------------------------+----- #>           Never | 179 (54.1%)  65 (38.5%) | 244  #>          Former | 107 (32.3%)  51 (30.2%) | 158  #>         Current | 45 (13.6%)   53 (31.4%) | 98   #> ----------------+-------------------------+----- #>             Sum |     331         169     | 500  #>  #>   Test: Pearson's Chi-squared test   p-value < 0.001

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: cross-sectional studies, often want Prevalence Ratio (PR). case-control studies, Odds Ratio (). tb() calculates confidence intervals automatically. Now know prevalence disease significantly different across smoking categories, can explore pr PR: Note: Without ref, function uses first factor level alphabetically. can look levels variable using levels(epitabl$smoking)
code: # Calculate Prevalence Ratio of Disease by Smoking status tb(epitabl, smoking, disease, col,     test = TRUE,     rp,            # Calculates Prevalence Ratios; change for or to get ORs    ref = "Never",     # Reference level for smoking group    conf.level = 0.95) # Define the level of confidence (0.95 by default)     #>                 | Disease status (primary outcome)  #>  Smoking status |     No          Yes     | Sum |    PR (95% CI)      #> ----------------+-------------------------+-----+-------------------- #>           Never | 179 (54.1%)  65 (38.5%) | 244 |     1.00 (Ref)      #>          Former | 107 (32.3%)  51 (30.2%) | 158 | 1.21 (0.89 - 1.65)  #>         Current | 45 (13.6%)   53 (31.4%) | 98  | 2.03 (1.54 - 2.68)  #> ----------------+-------------------------+-----+-------------------- #>             Sum |     331         169     | 500 |                     #>  #>   Test: Pearson's Chi-squared test   p-value < 0.001

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: continuous variables like age blood pressure, need tell tb() treat differently: default, get median interquartile range (IQR)—robust statistics aren’t thrown outliers. prefer mean standard deviation:
code: tb(epitabl, age, disease, var.type = c(age = "continuous")) #>                     |     Disease status (primary outcome)       #>        Age in years |         No                 Yes          #> --------------------+---------------------------------------- #>  age [Median (IQR)] | 49.0 (40.7 - 56.6)  55.9 (48.2 - 61.8)  #>  #>                     | Disease status (primary outcome)  #>        Age in years |       Total         #> --------------------+-------------------- #>  age [Median (IQR)] | 51.2 (43.1 - 58.3) tb(epitabl, systolic_bp, disease,     var.type = c(systolic_bp = "continuous"),    stat.cont = "mean") #>                                 |       Disease status (primary outcome)        #>  Systolic blood pressure (mmHg) |      No           Yes      |    Total      #> --------------------------------+----------------------------+-------------- #>         systolic_bp [Mean (SD)] | 111.6 (10.0)  123.1 (12.0) | 115.5 (12.0)

text: output tb() great console, publication, likely need polished table. SimtablR integrates seamlessly flextable package.  Disease status (primary outcome)   Smoking status Yes Sum PR (95% CI) Never 179 (54.1%) 65 (38.5%) 244 1.00 (Ref) Former 107 (32.3%) 51 (30.2%) 158 1.21 (0.89 - 1.65) Current 45 (13.6%) 53 (31.4%) 98 2.03 (1.54 - 2.68) Sum 331 169 500  Pearson's Chi-squared test: p-value < 0.001
code: # Create a table object table <- tb(epitabl, smoking, disease, col,           test = TRUE,           rp,                      ref = "Never",               conf.level = 0.95)   library(flextable) #load the flextable package to output into word or pptx ft <- as_flextable(table) ft <- autofit(ft)  # Optional: Adjust column widths ft save_as_docx(ft, path = "Table1.docx")  save_as_pptx(ft, path = "Table1.pptx")

what: Part 2: Diagnostic Test Evaluation with diag_test()
title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: Imagine ’re evaluating new rapid diagnostic test disease. gold standard laboratory confirmation. accurate, slow expensive. rapid test fast cheap, accurate enough? Let’s find !

previous_headings: Part 2: Diagnostic Test Evaluation with diag_test()
title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: diag_test() automates calculation Sensitivity, Specificity, Predictive Values (PPV/NPV), Likelihood Ratios. Let’s evaluate performance rapid_test lab_confirmed (Gold Standard) dataset. must define constitutes “Positive” result test reference. can quickly visualize Confusion Matrix using generic plot() function result object.  area quadrant reflects number observations. Large areas true positive true negative quadrants indicate good performance.
code: results <- diag_test(   data = epitabl,   test = rapid_test,   ref = lab_confirmed,   positive = "Yes" ) #> Removed 15 observation(s) with missing values (3.0%). #> Auto-detected test positive level: 'Positive'  print(results) #>  #> ============================================================ #>   DIAGNOSTIC TEST EVALUATION #> ============================================================ #>  #> Sample Size:       485  #> Confidence Level:  95%  #>  #> Reference Standard (Gold Standard): #>   Positive: 'Yes'  |  Negative: 'No' #>  #> Diagnostic Test: #>   Positive: 'Positive'  |  Negative: 'Negative' #>  #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Confusion Matrix: #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #>           Ref #> Test       Yes  No #>   Positive 143  37 #>   Negative  22 283 #>  #> ============================================================ #> Performance Metrics (with 95% CI): #> ============================================================ #> Sensitivity (Recall)  : 0.867 (0.805 - 0.915) #> Specificity           : 0.884 (0.844 - 0.917) #> Pos Pred Value (PPV)  : 0.794 (0.728 - 0.851) #> Neg Pred Value (NPV)  : 0.928 (0.893 - 0.954) #> Accuracy              : 0.878 (0.846 - 0.906) #> Prevalence            : 0.340 (0.298 - 0.384) #> ------------------------------------------------------------ #> Likelihood Ratio +    : 7.495 #> Likelihood Ratio -    : 0.151 #> Youden Index          : 0.751 #> F1 Score              : 0.829 plot(results, main = "Rapid Test Performance")

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: ’ve described data evaluated diagnostic test. Now want understand factors predict disease, healthcare utilization, outcomes multiple outcomes examine. use regtab(). Let’s say want understand healthcare utilization population. Specifically, ’ll examine three outcomes: Primary care visits (outcome1) Specialist visits (outcome2) Emergency department visits (outcome3) count variables, ’ll use Poisson regression. want know: age, sex, disease status, smoking affect type visit?

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: function fitted three separate Poisson regression models (one per outcome) using predictors outputs IIRs CIs
code: healthcare_model <- regtab(   data = epitabl,   outcomes = c("outcome1", "outcome2", "outcome3"),   predictors = ~ age + sex + disease + smoking,   family = poisson(link = "log"),   robust = TRUE,   labels = c(     outcome1 = "Primary Care",     outcome2 = "Specialist",     outcome3 = "Emergency Dept")   ) #> Auto-detected family 'poisson': Coefficients will be exponentiated.    print(healthcare_model) #>         Variable             Result  Outcome #> 1    (Intercept) 2.33 (1.91 - 2.83) outcome1 #> 2            age 1.01 (1.00 - 1.01) outcome1 #> 3        sexMale 1.02 (0.94 - 1.11) outcome1 #> 4     diseaseYes 1.62 (1.49 - 1.77) outcome1 #> 5  smokingFormer 0.99 (0.90 - 1.09) outcome1 #> 6 smokingCurrent 1.00 (0.90 - 1.12) outcome1

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: Now, let’s look risk factors Hospitalization (Binary: Yes/). coefficients now odds ratios
code: hospital_model <- regtab(   data = epitabl,   outcomes = "hospitalized",   predictors = ~ age + disease + smoking + comorbidity_score,   family = binomial(link = "logit") ) #> Auto-detected family 'binomial': Coefficients will be exponentiated.  print(hospital_model) #>            Variable             Result      Outcome #> 1       (Intercept) 0.01 (0.00 - 0.03) hospitalized #> 2               age 1.05 (1.02 - 1.07) hospitalized #> 3        diseaseYes 3.01 (1.76 - 5.13) hospitalized #> 4     smokingFormer 0.58 (0.30 - 1.12) hospitalized #> 5    smokingCurrent 2.74 (1.51 - 4.96) hospitalized #> 6 comorbidity_score 1.25 (0.83 - 1.89) hospitalized

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: Now outcome gets estimate column p-value column.
code: hospital_model_p <- regtab(   data = epitabl,   outcomes = "hospitalized",   predictors = ~ age + disease + smoking + comorbidity_score,   family = binomial(),   p_values = TRUE ) #> Auto-detected family 'binomial': Coefficients will be exponentiated.  print(hospital_model_p) #>            Variable             Result      Outcome P_Value #> 1       (Intercept) 0.01 (0.00 - 0.03) hospitalized  <0.001 #> 2               age 1.05 (1.02 - 1.07) hospitalized  <0.001 #> 3        diseaseYes 3.01 (1.76 - 5.13) hospitalized  <0.001 #> 4     smokingFormer 0.58 (0.30 - 1.12) hospitalized   0.106 #> 5    smokingCurrent 2.74 (1.51 - 4.96) hospitalized  <0.001 #> 6 comorbidity_score 1.25 (0.83 - 1.89) hospitalized   0.288

title: Introduction to SimtablR: Tables Made Simple
text: predicts blood pressure cholesterol? continuous outcomes, use Gaussian regression: linear (β) coefficients (exponentiated)
code: clinical_model <- regtab(   data = epitabl,   outcomes = c("systolic_bp", "cholesterol"),   predictors = ~ age + sex + bmi + exercise + smoking,   family = gaussian(),   labels = c(     systolic_bp = "Systolic BP (mmHg)",     cholesterol = "Cholesterol (mg/dL)"   ),   d = 1  # 1 decimal place )  print(clinical_model) #>           Variable             Result     Outcome #> 1      (Intercept) 71.2 (66.0 - 76.3) systolic_bp #> 2              age    0.5 (0.4 - 0.6) systolic_bp #> 3          sexMale  -1.0 (-2.6 - 0.6) systolic_bp #> 4              bmi    0.8 (0.6 - 1.0) systolic_bp #> 5 exerciseModerate -5.1 (-6.9 - -3.3) systolic_bp #> 6     exerciseHigh -6.5 (-8.8 - -4.2) systolic_bp #> 7    smokingFormer   1.1 (-0.8 - 3.0) systolic_bp #> 8   smokingCurrent    3.1 (1.0 - 5.2) systolic_bp

title: Publication-Ready Tables and Regression Analysis
text: SimtablR provides streamlined toolkit tabulating data calculating multi-outcome regression diagnostic accuracy metrics. aim package provide simple, easy--use core set functions can quickly generate pre-formatted tables ready export Excel, PowerPoint/Word (via flextable), simply formatted dataframes. tb() function built replace enhance base R table() function. just single word-argument, can add percentages, Prevalence Ratios (CIs!), Odds Ratios. used time-consuming process iterating variables now done single, fast function. regtab() streamlines process multi-outcome regressions, frequent epidemiological studies. Simply set predictors, regression method, define series outcomes (e.g., list symptoms). function run regression outcome, handle potential errors, calculate IRRs/ORs confidence intervals, format everything single table ready export.

title: Publication-Ready Tables and Regression Analysis
text: Let’s look basics SimtablR. First, load package included synthetic dataset: epitabl generic dataset containing demographic clinical variables common epidemiological studies.
code: library(SimtablR) # Load example data (included in the package) epitabl <- data(epitabl)

title: Publication-Ready Tables and Regression Analysis
text: tb( ) function generates one-way two-way tables. simply reference dataset, row variable, optionally column variable. Percentages & Styles can add percentages using flags: p (total %), row (row %), col (column %). can also customize display format using style argument (e.g., “pct_n” % (n)): Statistical Tests & Effect Measures Add p-values automatically test = TRUE. can also calculate Prevalence Ratios (PR) Odds Ratios () directly table: Stratification Need stratify third variable? Use strat argument:
code: # Simple cross-tabulation of Disease by Sex tb(epitabl, disease, sex) # Column percentages formatted as "25.5% (100)" tb(epitabl, disease, sex, col, style = "pct_n") # Add Chi-squared test and Prevalence Ratios tb(epitabl, disease, sex, col,     test = TRUE,     rp = TRUE,    # Calculates Prevalence Ratio    ref = "Yes") # Sets reference level # Add Chi-squared test and Prevalence Ratios # Disease vs Sex, stratified by Region tb(epitabl, disease, sex, strat = region, col)

title: Publication-Ready Tables and Regression Analysis
text: Evaluate binary tests gold standard. function auto-detects positive levels allows manual specification. can also visualize confusion matrix (early testing):
code: # Compare a 'Rapid Test' vs 'Lab Confirmation' results <- diag_test(epitabl,                       test = rapid_test,                       ref = lab_confirmed,                       positive = "Yes",          # Reference positive level                      test_positive = "Positive") # Test positive level  results plot(results, main = "Rapid Test Accuracy")

title: Publication-Ready Tables and Regression Analysis
text: Fit models multiple outcomes . regtab handles iteration, robust error calculation, formatting. Poisson Regression (IRR) can use formatting available tb regtab. , add labels outcomes, specify 3 decimal places using d define CI 99% Logistic Regression () Exporting Word/PowerPoint
code: # Assess the effect of Age and Sex on multiple outcomes (counts) regtab(epitabl,         outcomes = c("outcome1", "outcome2", "outcome3"),         predictors = "~ age + sex + smoking",         family = poisson(link = "log"),        robust = TRUE) # Uses robust standard errors poisson_table <- regtab(   data = epitabl,   outcomes = c("outcome1", "outcome2", "outcome3"),   predictors = ~ age + sex + smoking + bmi,   family = poisson(link = "log"),   robust = TRUE,   exponentiate = TRUE,  # Returns Incidence Rate Ratios   labels = c(     outcome1 = "Hospital Visits",     outcome2 = "ER Visits",     outcome3 = "Admissions"   ),   d = 2,   conf.level = 0.99 ) print(poisson_table) # Assess risk factors for Hospitalization regtab(epitabl,         outcomes = "hospitalized",         predictors = "~ age + bmi + comorbidity_score",         family = binomial(link = "logit")) tabela <- tb(epitabl, disease, sex, col, test = TRUE)  # Convert to flextable library(flextable) ft <- as_flextable(tabela) ft # You can now use save_as_docx(ft, path = "table1.docx")

title: Publication-Ready Tables and Regression Analysis
text: Core dependencies automatically installed. enhanced functionality:
code: # For flextable output (tb function) install.packages("flextable")  # For robust standard errors (regtab function) install.packages(c("sandwich", "lmtest"))  # For Excel export (regtab function) install.packages("openxlsx")

title: Multi-Outcome Regression Table — regtab
text: Fits generalized linear models (GLMs) multiple outcome variables generates formatted wide-format table point estimates confidence intervals. Supports robust standard errors, automatic exponentiation count/binary outcomes, custom labeling publication-ready tables.

title: Multi-Outcome Regression Table — regtab
code: regtab(   data,   outcomes,   predictors,   family = poisson(link = "log"),   robust = TRUE,   exponentiate = NULL,   labels = NULL,   d = 2,   conf.level = 0.95,   include_intercept = FALSE,   p_values = FALSE )

title: Multi-Outcome Regression Table — regtab
text: data Data.frame containing variables analysis. outcomes Character vector dependent variable names. outcome modeled separately set predictors. predictors Formula character string specifying predictors. Can : Formula: ~ x1 + x2 + x3 Character: "~ x1 + x2 + x3" "x1 + x2 + x3" family GLM family specification. Options: poisson(link = "log") - count outcomes (default) binomial(link = "logit") - binary outcomes gaussian(link = "identity") - continuous outcomes quasipoisson(), quasibinomial() - overdispersed data character: "poisson", "binomial", "gaussian" robust Logical. TRUE (default), calculates heteroskedasticity-consistent (HC0) robust standard errors via sandwich package. CIs based robust SEs. exponentiate Logical. TRUE, exponentiates coefficients CIs: Poisson: IRR (Incidence Rate Ratios) Binomial: (Odds Ratios) Gaussian: typically used (stays linear scale) NULL (default), automatically detects: TRUE Poisson/Binomial, FALSE Gaussian. labels Named character vector renaming outcome columns output. Format: c("raw_name" = "Pretty Label"). Useful publication tables. d Integer. Number decimal places rounding estimates CIs. Default: 2. conf.level Numeric. Confidence level intervals (0-1). Default: 0.95. include_intercept Logical. TRUE, includes intercept output table. Default: FALSE (typically excluded publication tables). p_values Logical. TRUE, adds p-values separate column. Default: FALSE.

title: Multi-Outcome Regression Table — regtab
code: # Create example data set.seed(456) n <- 500 df <- data.frame(   age = rnorm(n, 50, 10),   sex = factor(sample(c("M", "F"), n, replace = TRUE)),   treatment = factor(sample(c("A", "B"), n, replace = TRUE)),   outcome1 = rpois(n, lambda = 5),   outcome2 = rpois(n, lambda = 8),   outcome3 = rpois(n, lambda = 3) )  # Basic usage: Poisson regression for multiple outcomes regtab(df,        outcomes = c("outcome1", "outcome2", "outcome3"),        predictors = ~ age + sex + treatment,        family = poisson(link = "log")) #> Auto-detected family 'poisson': Coefficients will be exponentiated. #>      Variable             Result  Outcome #> 1 (Intercept) 4.98 (4.00 - 6.21) outcome1 #> 2         age 1.00 (1.00 - 1.00) outcome1 #> 3        sexM 1.05 (0.98 - 1.13) outcome1 #> 4  treatmentB 1.00 (0.93 - 1.08) outcome1  # With custom labels and no robust SEs regtab(df,        outcomes = c("outcome1", "outcome2"),        predictors = "age + sex",        labels = c(outcome1 = "Primary Endpoint", outcome2 = "Secondary Endpoint"),        robust = FALSE) #> Auto-detected family 'poisson': Coefficients will be exponentiated. #>      Variable             Result  Outcome #> 1 (Intercept) 4.99 (4.00 - 6.21) outcome1 #> 2         age 1.00 (1.00 - 1.00) outcome1 #> 3        sexM 1.05 (0.97 - 1.14) outcome1  # Logistic regression with p-values df$binary_outcome <- rbinom(n, 1, 0.4) regtab(df,        outcomes = "binary_outcome",        predictors = ~ age + sex,        family = binomial(),        p_values = TRUE) #> Auto-detected family 'binomial': Coefficients will be exponentiated. #>      Variable             Result        Outcome P_Value #> 1 (Intercept) 0.49 (0.18 - 1.33) binary_outcome   0.163 #> 2         age 1.01 (0.99 - 1.03) binary_outcome   0.346 #> 3        sexM 0.98 (0.68 - 1.40) binary_outcome   0.900

title: Frequency and Summary Tables — tb
text: data data.frame atomic vector. ... Variables tabulated. Can include variable names /flags (m, p, row, col, rp, ) controlling output format. m Logical. TRUE, includes missing values (NA) table. Default: FALSE. d Integer. Number decimal places percentages statistics. Default: 1. format Logical. TRUE, renders formatted grid output (Stata-style). FALSE, prints simple matrix. Default: TRUE. style Character. Format displaying counts percentages. Options: "n_pct": "100 (25.0\ "pct_n": "25.0\ Custom template using {n} {p} placeholders, e.g., "{n} [{p}%]". style.rp Character. Format string Prevalence Ratio. Default: "{rp} ({lower} - {upper})". style.Character. Format string Odds Ratio. Default: "{} ({lower} - {upper})". test Logical Character. Performs statistical test 2x2+ tables. TRUE: Automatic selection (chi-squared categorical) "chisq", "fisher", "mcnemar" subset Logical expression row filtering. strat Variable column stratification. Disables PR/calculations. rp Logical. TRUE, calculates Prevalence Ratios (PR). Logical. TRUE, calculates Odds Ratios (). ref Character numeric. Specifies reference level PR/calculations. conf.level Numeric. Confidence level intervals (0-1). Default: 0.95. var.type Named character vector specifying variable types. select line variable choose "continuous" "cont" ex: tb(epitabl, age, sex, var.type = c(age = "continuous")) stat.cont Character. "mean" (Mean/SD) "median" (Median/IQR).
